study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an adaptive assist-as-needed (AAN) control for a robotic exoskeleton could effectively assess and improve walking ability in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The AAN controller successfully reduced robotic support based on patient ability, with a linear model explaining 74% of variance in walking speed (10MWT) and 61% in mobility (TUG) for ambulatory patients. However, the approach was less effective for non-ambulatory and able-bodied individuals.
population_specificity: Fifteen participants with spinal cord injury and twelve controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rehabilitation interventions, including exercise-based therapies, on functional exercise capacity and quality of life in patients with post-COVID-19 condition (PCC).
results_summary: Rehabilitation interventions, including walking-based exercises, were associated with significant improvements in functional exercise capacity, dyspnea, and quality of life, with moderate certainty for functional exercise capacity and quality of life outcomes. However, there was uncertainty regarding the safety and probability of exercise-induced adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with post-COVID-19 condition (PCC), median age 50 years, 45% female.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of home-based walking exercise versus supervised treadmill exercise in improving walking ability in people with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Home-based walking exercise was associated with significantly greater improvement in 6-minute walk distance compared to supervised treadmill exercise, though supervised exercise showed better improvement in maximum treadmill walking distance. The findings support home-based walking as a first-line therapy for walking limitations in PAD.
population_specificity: People with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD), mean age 68.8 years, 46.5% female.
effective_dosage: Supervised treadmill exercise: 3 days weekly, up to 50 minutes per session. Home-based walking: up to 5 days per week, 50 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether combining pulsed electromagnetic field (PEMF) with progressive resistance exercise (PRE) improves physical function and pain in knee osteoarthritis patients compared to PRE alone.
results_summary: Both PRE alone and PRE with PEMF significantly improved pain (NPRS), physical function (KOOS), walking speed, and chair stand test performance at all follow-ups, with no significant differences between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Thirty-four elderly patients with knee osteoarthritis (17 per group).
study_duration: 2 months of treatment, with follow-ups at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: To determine the effect of low-intensity resistance training with blood flow restriction (LIRT-BFR) on lower extremity muscle strength, balance, functional mobility, walking capacity, and psychological outcomes in stroke survivors, compared to high-intensity resistance training (HIRT).
results_summary: LIRT-BFR significantly improved muscle strength, balance, walking capacity, and reduced anxiety and depression in ischemic stroke patients, with results comparable to HIRT. Both groups showed significant improvements in primary and secondary outcome measures.
population_specificity: 32 ischemic stroke survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize cardio-pulmonary sequelae, including functional impairments like dyspnea and walking capacity, in patients hospitalized for SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia at 24 months follow-up.
results_summary: At 24-month follow-up, 34% of patients exhibited some degree of dyspnea, and 26% had mild DLCO impairment. The 6-minute walking test was used as a functional assessment, but specific walking-related outcomes were not detailed beyond general cardio-pulmonary sequelae.
population_specificity: Consecutive patients hospitalized for COVID-19 and acute respiratory failure (74% men, median age 59.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of exoskeleton robot-assisted training (ERAT) on improving gait function in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: Six studies reported favorable effects of ERAT on gait performance, balance function, and physical endurance, while four trials showed equal or negative effects. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors (mean age 57.6 years, 63.2% males).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if robotic-assisted gait training (RAGT) could improve walking function in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: The study found that RAGT showed non-significant improvements in standing and walking function (Gross Motor Function Measure D, E), with changes in gait speed, step length, and cadence comparable to controls. The therapeutic effect of RAGT was likely not superior to physiotherapy combined with treadmill training.
population_specificity: Children under 18 years old with cerebral palsy (CP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop proniosome nanoparticles as a treatment for peripheral arterial disease (PAD), focusing on improving drug delivery and stability.
results_summary: The study found that proniosome nanoparticles exhibit good characteristics and effectiveness for treating PAD, enhancing drug stability and delivery without requiring special handling or storage conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative LCIG treatment followed by THA using a dual mobility cup could improve functional outcomes in a Parkinson's disease patient with rapidly destructive coxarthrosis.
results_summary: The study found that LCIG therapy improved motor symptoms (wearing-off and dyskinesia) preoperatively, and THA with a dual mobility cup led to improved walking speed, stride length, and hip function postoperatively without recurrence of adverse effects. The patient achieved satisfactory functional outcomes, including walking without a cane.
population_specificity: A 59-year-old female with severe Parkinson's disease and rapidly destructive coxarthrosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (LCIG therapy was initiated preoperatively and continued postoperatively).
study_duration: 2 months of LCIG therapy preoperatively, with follow-up at 1 year post-THA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze factors affecting long-term quality of life in mild stroke patients, with a focus on differences by age and sex, including the role of walking ability.
results_summary: Better walking ability (functional ambulatory category) was a predictor of higher quality of life in patients aged ≥65 years, while motor function (Fugl-Meyer assessment) predicted quality of life in those <65 years. Alcohol consumption and marital status also influenced outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with mild stroke (NIH Stroke Scale score <5) from the Korean Stroke Cohort for functioning and rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of aquatic therapy versus land-based exercises on motor and social skills as well as executive function in children with neurodevelopmental disorders.
results_summary: Aquatic therapy showed a more robust positive effect on factors related to the HAAR checklist, such as mental adjustment, compared to land-based exercises. The study included 16 trials with 248 children, using standardized mean differences for analysis.
population_specificity: Children with neurodevelopmental disorders

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of pulmonary rehabilitation combined with cognitive training on walking performance (6MWT) and cognitive parameters in male COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that pulmonary rehabilitation alone improved 6MWT distance and cognitive function, but combining it with cognitive training was more effective in enhancing cognitive abilities in COPD patients.
population_specificity: Tunisian male patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy and reliability of wireless pressure insoles versus force plates for measuring vertical ground reaction forces (vGRFs) and center of pressure (COP) trajectories during functional activities, including walking.
results_summary: The wireless insoles showed fair to high or excellent test-retest reliability for measuring vGRFs and COP trajectories during walking, though they consistently measured lower vGRFs and shorter medial-lateral COP trajectories compared to force plates. The qualitative similarity between the two systems suggests the insoles can reliably measure these outcomes for walking, depending on the required accuracy.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of carer-supported home-based exercise programs, including walking, for improving physical activity levels and functional mobility in people after stroke.
results_summary: The study found that carer-supported home-based exercise programs, which commonly included walking, improved functional mobility in five out of ten studies. However, physical activity levels were rarely objectively reported, and there was significant variation in carer training protocols.
population_specificity: People after stroke, supported by carers.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise interventions varied, commonly including walking, whole-body functional exercises, and balance activities).
study_duration: Carer training ranged from one to twelve sessions; intervention duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability and feasibility of a healthcare assistant-led walking intervention (iPOPP) for older people with persistent musculoskeletal pain in primary care.
results_summary: The study found the iPOPP intervention and a future full-scale RCT to be both acceptable and feasible, with all pre-specified success criteria met. Triangulation of data suggested improvements for patient-centered training and individualized goal setting.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥65 years with persistent musculoskeletal pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a prognostic model for predicting long-term survival in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension, using clinical risk factors including 6-minute walking distance.
results_summary: The study identified 6-minute walking distance as one of eight key variables in a prognostic model for predicting 5-year mortality risk, with the model showing good discrimination (C-index 0.77) and calibration. Walking distance contributed to risk stratification, aiding clinical decision-making.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension (n=310).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a home-based balance-intervention program delivered via smartphone versus traditional paper methods for improving balance performance in adults over 65.
results_summary: The study found no group differences in outcomes, with participants showing improved gait velocity (0.06 m/s faster) and modified balance strategies after the intervention. Both methods were similarly effective, enjoyable, and feasible.
population_specificity: Adults over the age of 65.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of exercise-based interventions, including pram walking, for managing postpartum depression (PPD) compared to usual care or other exercises.
results_summary: Pram walking was significantly associated with a reduction in depressive symptoms during the postpartum period, showing better efficacy than yoga and supervised mixed exercise, though the difference was not statistically significant. Exercise, in general, was effective in treating PPD symptoms.
population_specificity: Women aged 20-35 years with postpartum depression (1260 participants across 12 RCTs).

study_goal: To analyze the effect of combined training (aerobic plus strength) on postural control and gait parameters in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The combined training intervention improved gait (increased stride length and walking speed) and balance control (reduced postural sway and double support time) in postmenopausal women.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential connection between gut microbiota imbalances, neurotransmitter dysfunction, and idiopathic toe walking (ITW) in children.
results_summary: The study suggests ITW is heterogeneous and multifactorial, with some cases linked to genetic variants or sensorimotor impairment, and proposes a theoretical link between gut dysbiosis and neurotransmitter imbalances affecting motor control.
population_specificity: Children with idiopathic toe walking (ITW).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Zhenyuan capsule (ZYC) in treating chronic heart failure (CHF) compared to conventional treatment.
results_summary: The study found that ZYC combined with conventional treatment significantly improved clinical efficacy, increased left ventricular ejection fraction and 6-minute walk distance, and reduced brain natriuretic peptide levels. Safety results were comparable to conventional treatment but required further research.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on patellar malalignment (PM) management and emphasize its universality and importance in knee disorders, distinguishing between tibiofemoral (TF) and patellofemoral (PF) joint issues.
results_summary: The study highlights that patellar malalignment is common across age groups, often caused by imbalanced peripatellar soft-tissue tension, and discusses nonsurgical and surgical treatments with varying success rates. It emphasizes that focusing solely on TF joint problems cannot address all knee disorders.
population_specificity: Young individuals and all age groups with knee pain, particularly those with patellar malalignment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of moderate to vigorous intensity locomotor training (LT mv) on walking outcomes in subacute and chronic stroke patients and assess variability in response.
results_summary: LT mv significantly improved comfortable gait speed, fastest gait speed, and 6-minute walk test results in both subacute and chronic stroke patients, with no serious adverse events reported. However, no significant improvement was observed in daily walking activity (steps per day).
population_specificity: Subacute and chronic stroke patients (total N = 1096, with 839 chronic and 257 subacute).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether arm-in-arm gait training with a younger partner could improve gait patterns and reduce fall risk in older adults.
results_summary: The study expects arm-in-arm gait training to improve walking speed, gait quality, and reduce fall incidence, with high adherence and no adverse effects. Results will be compared between intervention and control groups.
population_specificity: Older adults (>70 years) with a history of falls and adequate walking ability, paired with younger "gait instructors."
study_duration: Four weeks of intervention, with follow-up at week 7 and fall monitoring over 18 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the frequency and diversity of physical function endpoints, including walking (6MWT), in cancer cachexia trials to determine optimal measures for future studies.
results_summary: The 6-minute walking test (6MWT) was assessed in 12 trials (n=1074) and showed statistically significant results in 4 trials (33%, n=403). However, heterogeneity in study design and endpoint selection made it difficult to determine the optimal measure.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) with cancer cachexia participating in controlled trials with >40 participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy of soft robotic exosuits (SREs) in improving walking ability and biomechanical properties in stroke patients.
results_summary: SREs improved walking speed, distance, peak ankle dorsiflexion angle, peak paretic propulsion, stride length, and compensated gait in stroke patients, showing both immediate and training effects. However, the small number of studies limits generalizability.
population_specificity: Patients with post-stroke hemiparesis (83 participants across 9 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of total hip arthroplasty (THA) in patients with acute Mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) hip infections, focusing on clinical and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that THA significantly improved clinical, radiological, and functional outcomes (e.g., walking ability, pain scores, and Harris hip scores) in patients with active TB arthritis of the hip, with a mean Harris hip score of 91.36 at final follow-up. Surgery was deemed safe and effective when performed under a multi-drug anti-tubercular regimen.
population_specificity: Patients with acute Mycobacterium tuberculosis arthritis of the hip (mean age: 34 to 52 years).
study_duration: Mean follow-up ranged from 2.5 to 10.5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a nurse-led, self-determination theory-based physical activity program (including Tai Chi and walking) on physical activity, osteosarcopenic outcomes, and quality of life in postmenopausal women with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in physical activity, perceived sarcopenia, grip strength, walking speed, disease activity score, and health-related quality of life compared to the control group. The program was deemed effective and feasible for this population.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with rheumatoid arthritis in South Korea.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included Tai Chi-based physical activity, psychosocial strategies, and interactive counseling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of percutaneous image-guided lumbar decompression (mild procedure) combined with conventional medical management (CMM) versus CMM alone for treating lumbar spinal stenosis with neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: The mild + CMM group showed significant improvements in all outcome measures, including walking tolerance, pain, and disability, over two years. Most CMM-alone patients opted for the mild procedure or other interventions by the two-year mark, and no device- or procedure-related adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis and neurogenic claudication secondary to hypertrophic ligamentum flavum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two treadmill perturbation-based balance training (PBT) protocols for improving reactive balance control in fall-prone older adults and evaluate their feasibility and acceptability.
results_summary: The study found that PBT shows promise for improving reactive balance control in fall-prone older adults, with effectiveness measured via Stepping Threshold Test (STT) and Dynamic Stepping Threshold Test (DSTT). Secondary outcomes included improvements in spatiotemporal and kinematic parameters, balance, physical capacity, and executive functions.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling, fall-prone older adults (Timed Up and Go >12 s, habitual gait speed <1.0 m/s, and/or fall history).
effective_dosage: Six or two treadmill PBT sessions (40 perturbations per session) plus four conventional treadmill training sessions, conducted once weekly for 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of mobilization and weightbearing versus immobilization and non-weightbearing in patients with stable transsyndesmotic, lateral isolated simple ankle fractures.
results_summary: The intervention group (permissive weightbearing in a walking boot) showed significantly higher ankle functionality, improved range of motion, and better physical and mental health outcomes compared to the non-weightbearing group. All fractures demonstrated radiological healing progression, though 16% of initially stable fractures showed joint dislocation upon weightbearing.
population_specificity: Patients with stable Weber B fractures (transsyndesmotic, isolated lateral simple ankle fractures).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved permissive weightbearing in a walking boot).
study_duration: 24 months of follow-up (intervention duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aerobic exercises, including walking, on arterial stiffness in older people.
results_summary: Aerobic exercises, including walking, improved pulse wave velocity and other arterial stiffness markers in older people, particularly when the intervention lasted more than 8 weeks. No significant improvements were observed in the augmentation index, arterial compliance, or beta stiffness index.
population_specificity: Older people (healthy and those with diseases).
study_duration: Interventions lasting >8 weeks showed significant improvements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility, acceptability, safety, and potential efficacy of inspiratory muscle training (IMT) combined with walking to address dyspnea and physical inactivity in lung cancer survivors post-therapy.
results_summary: The study found that telemedicine-based IMT + walking was feasible, acceptable, and safe, with significant improvements in health-related quality of life (HRQL) for intervention participants compared to controls. No statistically significant differences in safety events were observed between groups.
population_specificity: Lung cancer survivors who completed curative-intent therapy within 1-6 months.
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking; IMT was performed at the recommended dose by 75% of participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how factors like comorbidities, fracture type, treatments, and complications influenced outcomes, including independent walking, in elderly patients with hip fractures.
results_summary: Independent walking was significantly better in intracapsular fractures than extracapsular fractures, and early surgery led to better prognoses. However, most patients remained dependent on assistance for daily activities even after one year, and health-related quality of life was impaired post-surgery.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 78 years, 80% female) with hip fractures above 65 years of age.
study_duration: Follow-up for up to 1 year post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the analgesic effect and safety of duloxetine for patients undergoing total knee or hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: Duloxetine significantly reduced opioid requirements and early postoperative pain (24-hour and 1-week visual analog scores) without increasing adverse effects. However, no significant differences were observed in numeric rating scales or longer-term outcomes (6-week and 3-month periods).
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee or hip arthroplasty.
study_duration: Postoperative periods assessed included 24 hours, 1 week, 6 weeks, and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a multilevel, multicomponent intervention (environmental, individual, or combined) could increase moderate-intensity physical activity (e.g., walking) among low-income residents in U.S. public housing over 2 years.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that participants in any intervention group (environmental, individual, or combined) would increase moderate-intensity physical activity more than the control group, with the combined intervention expected to improve activity levels to recommended guidelines. Results were not yet reported as the study was ongoing.
population_specificity: Low-income adults living in U.S. public housing developments.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included walking groups, advocacy programs, and a 12-week automated telephone program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of transcatheter edge-to-edge repair (TEER) on tricuspid regurgitation severity and related outcomes, including 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in 6MWD at 1 year (P = 0.001) post-TEER, alongside improvements in TR severity and NYHA class. No significant changes were observed in left ventricular ejection fraction or other cardiac parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe (grade III-V) tricuspid regurgitation undergoing isolated TEER.
study_duration: Outcomes assessed at 30 days and 1 year post-procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an 8-figure shoulder brace during treadmill training (8-FSBTT) versus treadmill training alone (OT) on arm swing angle and gait parameters in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The 8-FSBTT group showed significant improvements in arm swing angle, gait speed, cadence, and stride lengths after 4 weeks of training compared to baseline. The study concluded that 8-FSBTT combined with standard physiotherapy enhanced walking ability in chronic stroke patients.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients

study_goal: To investigate the effect of botulinum toxin type A (BoNT-A) injections in the rectus femoris on gait kinematics and functional outcomes in adult stroke patients with stiff knee gait.
results_summary: BoNT-A injections significantly increased peak knee flexion (6.7°) and knee range of motion (4.8°) compared to placebo, with no effect on hip kinematics. The 6 Minute Walking Test showed a significant improvement of 18.3 m, but other functional outcomes did not differ.
population_specificity: Adult stroke patients with stiff knee gait

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a game-based intradialytic exercise training program (iExergame) on improving gait speed and balance in older adults with diabetes receiving hemodialysis.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in gait speed, stride length, and balance parameters (reduced center of mass, ankle, and hip sways) compared to the control group, particularly during dual-task walking and in users of assistive devices.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 64.2 ± 9.0 years) with diabetes receiving hemodialysis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intradialytic, non-weight-bearing ankle range of motion exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a behavioral intervention combining weight loss and walking exercise improves 6-minute walk distance in obese/overweight individuals with peripheral artery disease (PAD) compared to walking exercise alone.
results_summary: The study tested the effects of a weight loss and walking intervention versus walking alone on mobility in PAD patients, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome results.
population_specificity: 212 participants with PAD and a body mass index ≥25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher postoperative physical activity (including walking) improves overall survival after tumor recurrence in stage III colon cancer patients.
results_summary: Patients with ≥18.0 MET-h/week of physical activity (comparable to 6 hours of brisk walking weekly) had a 33% relative improvement in overall survival after tumor recurrence compared to those with <3.0 MET-h/week. The 3-year survival rate was 72.2% for the high-activity group versus 61.3% for the low-activity group.
population_specificity: Patients initially diagnosed with stage III colon cancer who experienced tumor recurrence (N = 399).
effective_dosage: ≥18.0 MET-h/week (comparable to 6 hours of brisk walking weekly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between muscle strength, functional capacity, and quality of life in individuals with ALS, focusing on walking and other motor functions.
results_summary: The study found that lower-extremity strength strongly correlated with gross motor function and walking-related quality of life in ALS patients, suggesting muscle strength directly impacts walking ability. Upper-extremity strength also showed significant correlations with fine motor function.
population_specificity: 456 participants with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) from the FORTITUDE-ALS clinical trial.

study_goal: To examine the effects of end-effector robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) on gait and balance abilities in patients with spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Both RAGT and conventional therapy improved gait ability, lower extremity muscle strength, balance, proprioception, and mobility, with RAGT showing significantly greater improvements in balance and gait abilities compared to conventional therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze clinical presentations of cerebellar impairment (PwCI) to differentiate cerebellar and non-cerebellar symptoms and identify interventions and assessments impacting walking and mobility.
results_summary: The study found that activity-based interventions (e.g., gait training, tai chi) improved mobility in PwCI, but outcomes on body function (ataxia, gait pattern) were reported in only 22% of cases. Multimodal, patient-tailored strategies showed promise for addressing walking and mobility in cerebellar impairment.
population_specificity: Persons with cerebellar impairment (38 patients from 28 case-reports, spanning 14 etiologies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of a musicokinetic (MSK) program on anxiety levels, kinematic/kinetic parameters, and frontal cortex hemodynamic responses during gait initiation and steady-state walking in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study focused on assessing acute effects of the MSK program on walking-related outcomes in PD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week physical activity intervention, including walking, could reduce perceived caregiver burden and symptoms of depression in caregivers of patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found that the physical activity intervention significantly reduced Zarit Caregiver Burden Scale and Beck Depression Inventory scores in the intervention group compared to baseline, indicating improved caregiver burden and depression symptoms.
population_specificity: Family caregivers of patients with schizophrenia.
effective_dosage: 40 minutes of free walking per session, 12 sessions total.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and therapeutic effects of autologous bone marrow mononuclear cells (auto-BM-MNC) versus allogeneic Wharton jelly-derived mesenchymal stem cells (allo-WJ-MSCs) in diabetic patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).
results_summary: The study found that both auto-BM-MNC and allo-WJ-MSCs improved Rutherford's classification and transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPO2), with 100% limb conservation over 12 months. The allo-WJ-MSC group showed faster improvement compared to the auto-BM-MNC group, while the placebo group had a 60% amputation rate.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with advanced-stage CLTI (Rutherford's classification 4 or 5).

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of joint mobilization combined with acupuncture for improving pain, physical function, and depression in poststroke patients.
results_summary: The combination of joint mobilization and acupuncture significantly improved pain and physical function compared to joint mobilization alone or control. Both intervention groups showed significant improvements in physical function and depression compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Poststroke patients with chronic neuropathic pain (n = 69).
effective_dosage: Joint mobilization for 30 minutes, twice a week; acupuncture for 30 minutes, once a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether strength training, including walking-related functional performance, could be successfully integrated into long-term clinical care for outpatients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found that strength training improved leg press strength and power, as well as sit-to-stand performance, but walking work efficiency improved similarly in both the training and control groups without significant differences between them. Stair climbing performance remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Outpatients with schizophrenia (28 men and 20 women, mean age 35 ± 11 years).
effective_dosage: Leg press maximal strength training (4 sets at 90% of 1RM, 2×/week).

study_goal: To examine the impact of interrupting prolonged sitting with frequent short bouts of light-intensity walking on glycaemic control in people with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: Interrupting sitting with 3-minute walking bouts every 30 minutes significantly improved glycaemic control, reducing mean glucose levels, increasing time in the target range, and decreasing hyperglycaemia without increasing hypoglycaemia risk. These benefits persisted during both experimental and free-living conditions.
population_specificity: 32 inactive adults with type 1 diabetes (aged 27.9 ± 4.7 years, 15 men, diabetes duration 16.0 ± 6.9 years).
effective_dosage: 3-minute bouts of self-paced walking at 30-minute intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an 18-month telehealth walking exercise self-management program improves walking exercise sustainability compared to attention-control education in veterans with lower-limb amputation.
results_summary: The study will assess daily walking step count (primary outcome) and secondary outcomes like intervention reach, efficacy, clinical adoption, implementation potential, and long-term exercise maintenance. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Veterans aged 50-89 with lower-limb amputation (traumatic or nontraumatic).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention includes 6 one-on-one and 6 group sessions over 18 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of exercise interventions on gait outcomes in people with lower-limb amputation (PLLA) at subacute and chronic stages of recovery.
results_summary: The study found that multicomponent exercise programs (gait, balance, and strength training) improved gait outcomes in PLLA, with small improvements in the subacute phase and moderate improvements in the chronic phase. The optimal duration and frequency of exercise remain unclear due to variation between interventions.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) with lower-limb amputation who used a prosthesis for walking.
effective_dosage: Subacute: 30 minutes, 1-7 times/week; Chronic: 15-60 minutes, 2-3 times/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking combined with tDCS or sham tDCS improves cognitive function in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that walking combined with tDCS (WAT) or sham tDCS (WAS) was compared to Tai Chi interventions, but the abstract does not specify the relative efficacy of walking alone or its combination with tDCS on cognitive outcomes.
population_specificity: 180 participants with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and effects of a nurse-led protocol for early mobilization (walking) within 4 hours after transfemoral transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) in hospitalized older patients.
results_summary: The study found that 70.5% of patients were successfully mobilized within 4 hours, and 84.9% were walking by the evening of the procedure. Delays in mobilization were primarily due to clinical complications (e.g., arrhythmia, hemodynamic instability) or system issues.
population_specificity: Older hospitalized patients (mean age 82.5 years, 46% women) who underwent transfemoral TAVI.
study_duration: Immediate post-procedure period (within 8 hours to next day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding cervical stabilization exercises (CSEs) to conventional exercises (CEs) improves outcomes like posture, balance, and walking speed in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in trunk rotation angle, pelvic asymmetry, TUG test time, and 10MWT. Adding CSEs to CEs led to greater improvements in joint position sense (JPS) and postural control compared to CEs alone.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (n=18 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of comprehensive and simple multicomponent exercise programs (including walking) on physical function in older hospitalized adults versus usual care.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a planned comparison of exercise interventions, but results are not yet reported as it is a trial protocol. The primary outcome will assess physical function at discharge and 3 months post-discharge.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥75 years from geriatric medical departments in Stockholm, Sweden.
effective_dosage: Not specified (simple exercise program includes walking and sit-to-stand exercises).
study_duration: Assessments at admission, discharge, and 3 months post-discharge; readmissions tracked up to 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of Robotic Locomotor Training (RLT) compared to Activity-based Training (ABT) for improving functional strength and walking capacity in individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that both RLT and ABT groups showed significant improvements in upper extremity motor scores and abdominal strength, but only the RLT group demonstrated significant gains in lower extremity motor scores and walking distance. The intervention was feasible with high attendance and low drop-out rates.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic traumatic motor incomplete tetraplegia (spinal cord injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether walking interventions improve cognitive function in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Walking interventions showed no significant improvement in cognitive function but significantly improved aerobic capacity (measured by the 6-minute walk test) in individuals with MCI.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the level of evidence for the clinically significant effects of gait modification on knee pain and determine if these effects exceed the minimal clinically important difference (MCID).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that gait modification had significant effects on knee pain (p=0.02), but the quality of evidence was very low. Some studies suggested that foot-focused gait modification may have clinically significant effects exceeding the MCID.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee pain, likely due to knee osteoarthritis (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of podiatric pathology in people with breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy and its impact on foot health and walking limitations.
results_summary: The study found high prevalence of foot health problems, including nail changes, xerosis, and neuropathic symptoms, with 65.8% of participants reporting limitations in walking. Most participants rated their foot health as fair or poor.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy (n=117, ≥18 years old) in northwest Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the application of machine learning in orthopedic research, including its potential to analyze walking for determining osteoarthritis stages.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that machine learning models have been used to determine the stage of osteoarthritis based on walking analysis, but it does not provide specific results or outcomes related to walking itself.
population_specificity: Not specified (general orthopedic research context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of hybrid comprehensive telerehabilitation (HCTR) compared to usual rehabilitation care for cardiovascular disease (CVD) patients.
results_summary: HCTR was found to be as effective as traditional rehabilitation care in reducing readmission rates and mortality while improving quality of life in CVD patients, with additional benefits in improving VO₂.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular disease (CVD).

study_goal: To determine whether the use of an augmented reality (AR) walkthrough affects patient perioperative anxiety compared to standard education.
results_summary: The AR group experienced a significant decrease in preoperative anxiety compared to the standard care group, but no significant differences were observed in postoperative anxiety, pain levels, or narcotic use. Most AR group participants reported enjoying the experience and would recommend or use it again.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective orthopedic surgery (mean age 38 years, 66.3% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a pedometer-based walking intervention, combined with face-to-face sessions and regular telephone contact, improves functional capacity in heart failure patients.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but the abstract outlines the planned statistical analyses to evaluate changes in the 6-minute walk test distance over 6 months. Adverse events are monitored, but no specific results are reported yet.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether financially incentivizing public transport use could increase physical activity, particularly walking, among infrequent bus users.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a smaller decline in daily steps compared to the control group and a significant increase in transport-related physical activity (walking and cycling), while total physical activity saw little change. The control group experienced a decrease in transport-related physical activity but an increase in total physical activity.
population_specificity: Australian adults (≥ 18 years) who were infrequent bus users (≤ 2 times/week).
effective_dosage: Not specified (incentives were awarded based on meeting targets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a history of falls affected physical activity levels and sedentary behavior after implementing a behavior modification approach in patients with minor ischemic stroke.
results_summary: The study found that patients with a history of falls showed a significantly smaller increase in step count compared to those without a history of falls, suggesting they may have engaged in activities other than walking. No significant differences were observed in other physical activity levels or sedentary behavior.
population_specificity: Patients with minor ischemic stroke (n=52).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of tricuspid transcatheter edge-to-edge repair using the TriClip implant in patients with symptomatic moderate or greater tricuspid regurgitation.
results_summary: The study found that TR was reduced to moderate or less in 60% of subjects, with sustained benefits in TR reduction, functional improvements, and reduced hospitalization rates over 2 years.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic moderate or greater tricuspid regurgitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if quantifying both absolute and relative intensity of accelerometer-assessed physical activity (PA) could inform PA interventions, hypothesizing that individuals with low relative intensity PA would be more likely to increase PA in response to an intervention.
results_summary: The study found that low relative intensity of PA at baseline was associated with increased absolute PA intensity post-intervention, while high relative intensity was associated with decreased absolute intensity. The intervention did not improve overall PA volume.
population_specificity: 239 participants (86% male, average age 66.4) who had experienced cardiac events.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the timeline and factors influencing bone mineral density (BMD) loss and recovery after combat-related lower extremity amputations, with a focus on the role of walking and other interventions.
results_summary: The study found that both amputated and non-amputated limbs experienced significant BMD loss, stabilizing around 3 years post-injury. Walking (nonambulatory status) was associated with a -33.5 HU reduction in BMD, while factors like transtibial amputation and surgical complications also influenced outcomes.
population_specificity: Military personnel with combat-related lower extremity amputations (2003-2016).
study_duration: Follow-up spanned multiple years, with BMD stabilization observed after ~1,000 days.

study_goal: To investigate whether water exercise therapy improves lower limb function rehabilitation in first-time stroke patients.
results_summary: The hydrotherapy group showed significant improvements in lower limb motor function (FMA), walking ability (FAC), balance (BBS), and daily living ability (MBI) compared to the control group after 8 weeks of treatment.
population_specificity: 160 first-time stroke patients with lower limb dysfunction from a geriatric hospital in China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (underwater exercise training combined with conventional therapy).

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Walking or any related study goals.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide any results related to Walking.
population_specificity: Not mentioned (abstract focuses on spinal muscular atrophy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand why older adults do not walk faster despite being able to, by examining changes in regional oxygenated haemoglobin (HbO2) in the frontal lobe during walking at preferred and fast speeds.
results_summary: The study found increased HbO2 in the supplementary motor area and primary motor cortex in older adults when walking fast, suggesting neural adaptations may limit gait speed in aging. Gait was quantified using accelerometer data, showing differences between young and older adults.
population_specificity: 17 young adults and 18 older adults.
effective_dosage: Walking at preferred speed and fast speed (120% of preferred) for 30-second intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the feasibility and effectiveness of contextual sensory integration (C.S.I.) training via virtual reality to traditional vestibular rehabilitation for improving symptoms and function in patients with vestibular dysfunction.
results_summary: Both traditional vestibular rehabilitation and C.S.I. training led to significant improvements in dizziness, balance confidence, visual vertigo, and functional gait, with no significant differences between the two methods. No improvements were observed in timed mobility tests (TUG and FSST).
population_specificity: Thirty patients with vestibular dysfunction (final sample: 18 completers).
effective_dosage: Once per week in-clinic sessions plus a home exercise program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose a basic model for specialized heart failure clinics (HFCs) in Egypt, including the role of functional assessments like the 6-minute walking test in patient management.
results_summary: The study highlighted the importance of functional assessments, including the 6-minute walking test, as part of comprehensive heart failure management in HFCs. It emphasized guideline-directed therapy and multidisciplinary care to improve patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients in Egypt, with potential applicability to low-to-middle income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate fixed-intensity exercise tests, including walking, for assessing exertional dyspnoea in chronic cardiopulmonary populations.
results_summary: Walking was one of the modes used in fixed-intensity exercise tests, with 31 studies included. Most studies focused on chronic respiratory disease patients, and exertional dyspnoea was commonly measured using the Borg scale.
population_specificity: Chronic cardiopulmonary disease populations, primarily chronic respiratory disease patients.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of overground gait training with the MARS robotic system on gait parameters in stroke patients.
results_summary: Both sub-acute and chronic stroke patients showed significant improvements in walking speed, endurance, balance, and independence after 12 sessions of MARS-assisted gait training, with no adverse events reported. The chronic stroke group demonstrated clinically meaningful improvements in endurance, while both groups showed better balance outcomes.
population_specificity: 29 adult stroke patients (≤65 years), divided into sub-acute (≤6 months post-stroke) and chronic (>6 months post-stroke) groups.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions (1 hour per session) over 2-3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of a WeChat-based education and rehabilitation program (WERP) on physical performance and quality of life in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) post percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
results_summary: The study found that the WERP group showed higher Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) scores, longer 6-minute walking distances (6MWT), and improved quality of life (EQ-5D and EQ-VAS scores) compared to the control group at multiple follow-up points. Patients with lower baseline SPPB scores benefited more from the intervention.
population_specificity: 180 patients with ACS after PCI.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program duration and frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) programs versus conventional setups in improving postoperative mobility and pain outcomes for patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (THA).
results_summary: The ERAS group showed significantly better mobility (measured by TUG and walking distance) up to the sixth postoperative day and superior activity subitems on the first and second days, with no significant difference in pain scores between groups. No complications were reported in either group.
population_specificity: 194 patients undergoing THA procedures.
study_duration: Up to the sixth postoperative day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure knee hyperextension and femoral cartilage thickness in stroke patients and compare cartilage thickness between paretic and nonparetic limbs in those with and without knee hyperextension.
results_summary: The study found that stroke patients with knee hyperextension had reduced femoral cartilage thickness on the paretic side compared to the nonparetic side, suggesting that knee hyperextension during walking contributes to cartilage degeneration.
population_specificity: Forty stroke patients, divided into groups with and without knee hyperextension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding dural decompression (duroplasty) to standard bony decompression improves muscle strength and functional outcomes, including walking, in patients with acute, severe traumatic cervical spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking outcomes, as the study is ongoing and outcomes will be assessed at 6 and 12 months post-randomization.
population_specificity: Adults with acute, severe traumatic cervical spinal cord injury (ASIA Impairment Scale grade A, B, or C).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 6 and 12 months post-randomization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the evidence on the effects of virtual reality (VR) on biomechanical gait parameters in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The review analyzed seven studies, focusing on treadmill-based VR interventions, but the abstract does not provide specific findings on gait parameter changes.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the characteristics and effects of walking interventions on cognitive function in patients with non-CNS cancer.
results_summary: Moderate-intensity walking interventions (40-60% maximal heart rate) improved objective cognitive domains like processing speed and spatial working memory, with small to moderate effect sizes. Home-based walking also showed borderline significant positive effects on perceived cognitive function during chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Adults with non-central nervous system (non-CNS) cancer.
effective_dosage: Moderate intensity at 40-60% maximal heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether digital health technology, combining comprehensive geriatric assessment and gait parameters, could effectively predict frailty in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that a machine learning model combining CGA and gait parameters predicted frailty with high accuracy (AUC 0.93), outperforming models using either feature alone. Key predictive features included large-step walking speed, average step size, age, total step walking distance, and cognitive scores.
population_specificity: 214 independently living older adults in Southern China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare and rank the effectiveness of different types of exercise, including walking, on walking capacity, cardiorespiratory fitness, dialysis adequacy, and health-related quality of life in patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis (MHD).
results_summary: The study found that intradialytic combined aerobic and resistance exercise was optimal for improving multiple outcomes, including walking capacity, which could be further enhanced by combining blood flow restriction with exercise. Intradialytic exercise was more effective than non-intradialytic exercise for improving dialysis adequacy.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis (MHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the optimal dose and type of physical activity, including walking, to improve functional capacity and reduce adverse events in acutely hospitalized older adults.
results_summary: The study found that as little as ~25 min/day of slow-paced walking improved functional capacity and minimized adverse events, with the optimal dose estimated at ~50 min/day. Physical activity interventions, particularly ambulation, were effective and safe, showing a decrease in adverse events compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Acutely hospitalized older adults aged ≥50 years.
effective_dosage: Minimal effective dose: ~25 min/day of slow-paced walking (74 METs-min/day); optimal dose: ~50 min/day (143 METs-min/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of percutaneous ultrasound tenotomy (PUT) using the TENEX® device for improving pain and functional outcomes, including walking tolerance, in patients with refractory iliotibial band (ITB) tendinopathy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain (NRS-11 reduced by 4 points) and functional outcomes, with 66% of patients showing improved walking tolerance at one-year follow-up.
population_specificity: Adults with refractory trochanteric pain due to ITB tendinopathy, predominantly older women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop clinical prediction rules (CPRs) to determine multi-surface walking independence in persons with stroke.
results_summary: The study identified Berg Balance Scale (BBS), comfortable walking speed (CWS), and cognitive impairment as factors in the BBS-model CPR, and Mini-BESTest as a factor in the Mini-BESTest-model CPR. Both models showed high accuracy, with the BBS model having an AUC of 0.89 and the Mini-BESTest model an AUC of 0.72.
population_specificity: 419 persons with stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether trimetazidine, a fatty acid oxidation inhibitor, could improve myocardial energy homeostasis and exercise hemodynamics in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: Trimetazidine did not improve myocardial energy homeostasis or exercise hemodynamics in patients with HFpEF. The study found no significant benefit in the primary or secondary endpoints.
population_specificity: 25 patients with HFpEF (10 males, 15 females; mean age 66 years; BMI 29.8 kg/m²).
study_duration: 3 months per treatment arm, with a 2-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different durations of aerobic exercise, including walking, on glycemic levels and BMI in prediabetic patients.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise, including walking, significantly reduced BMI and improved glycemic markers (FBG, 2hPG, HbA1c) in prediabetic patients compared to controls. The extent of improvement varied slightly with exercise duration.
population_specificity: Prediabetic patients (average age 56.1 years, 39.2% male).
effective_dosage: Training sessions occurred 3-4 times per week (specific walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy and safety of percutaneous transluminal pulmonary angioplasty (PTPA) for Takayasu arteritis-associated pulmonary hypertension (TA-PH), including its impact on exercise tolerance measured by 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found that PTPA improved hemodynamics (reduced pulmonary vascular resistance) and exercise tolerance (increased 6MWD) in TA-PH patients, though with procedure-related complications. The findings suggest PTPA could benefit TA-PH treatment but require further validation via randomized controlled trials.
population_specificity: 104 patients with Takayasu arteritis-associated pulmonary hypertension (TA-PH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if individuals with hip-related pain (HRP) exhibit altered ankle and hip kinetics during walking compared to healthy controls, and whether these patterns differ by sex.
results_summary: Females with HRP showed reduced hip flexion impulse and peak ankle plantarflexion moment compared to healthy controls and their contralateral limb, while males with HRP exhibited no significant differences. The findings suggest sex-specific kinetic adaptations in HRP during walking.
population_specificity: 42 individuals with hip-related pain (HRP) and 20 healthy controls (HCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality of evidence from randomized or quasi-randomized controlled trials using virtual reality-based games to improve balance and/or gait in children and adolescents with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).
results_summary: The review found very low-quality evidence for balance improvement with virtual reality-based games and no significant difference compared to traditional balance exercises. No trials evaluated gait outcomes.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 6-19 years with bilateral SNHL and no other physical, cognitive, or neurological deficits except vestibular dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prognosis and effectiveness of early disease-modifying treatments in spinal muscular atrophy, particularly in cases where the disease presents very early.
results_summary: The study reviewed data from 18 publications, indicating that early treatment outcomes depend on the number of SMN2 copies, but the abstract does not provide specific results related to walking.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal muscular atrophy, particularly those treated presymptomatically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare treatment outcomes (including walking function) between patients with metastatic femoral tumors who underwent preventative intramedullary nailing versus those who had surgery after pathological fracture.
results_summary: Patients in the preventative (impending fracture) group had significantly better walking function recovery, shorter surgery duration, less blood loss, shorter hospital stays, and longer postoperative survival compared to the completed fracture group.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic femoral tumors (excluding hematological malignancies), divided into an impending fracture group (n=11) and a completed fracture group (n=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the use of wearable sensor technologies for assessing and monitoring motor function in people with multiple sclerosis (MS) during daily activities or in controlled settings.
results_summary: The review included 308 studies, with most focusing on physical activity (63.6%) and gait (26.3%). Wearable sensors, particularly triaxial accelerometers, were commonly used, showing potential for optimizing MS management but highlighted limitations like lack of harmonization and transparency in reporting.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if silkworm pupae extract (SWP) combined with low-intensity exercise (walking) improves muscle mass and strength in middle-aged and older adults with low skeletal muscle mass.
results_summary: SWP did not significantly improve knee strength or body composition but showed modest increases in handgrip strength compared to placebo. No adverse effects were reported in the SWP group, while the placebo group had minor side effects.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults (64.4 ± 6.1 years) with relatively low skeletal muscle mass.
effective_dosage: 1000 mg SWP/day plus 30-60 minutes/day of walking ≥3 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the benefits of a multicomponent training program, including walking, on functional mobility and physical fitness in institutionalized older adults.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in functional mobility (TUG, 10MWT, 6'WT) and physical fitness (SPPB) compared to the control group, but no significant changes in independence or maximum muscle power/strength.
population_specificity: Institutionalized older adults aged 70 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically assess the effect of Qigong exercise on motor function in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that Qigong exercise improved balance function, limb motor function, walking function, and trunk function in stroke patients, with statistically significant results across multiple measures.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (1,487 participants across 19 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of walking on cognitive function in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and identify associated biomarkers.
results_summary: The walking group showed some improvement in cognitive function, though the combination exercise group (TCE + RTG) demonstrated more significant benefits in memory and general cognitive function. Peripheral blood BDNF levels were associated with cognitive improvement.
population_specificity: Older adults (ages 60-80) with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, 3 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient and staff experiences of best-practice rehabilitation advice versus progressive functional exercise for ankle fracture recovery.
results_summary: Both interventions were acceptable, but progressive exercise was highly valued by patients for improving strength, motion, and activity ability. Staff and patients appreciated physiotherapy expertise, individualized plans, and active monitoring.
population_specificity: Patients over 50 years old (median 66) with ankle fractures, 6 months post-injury, from three NHS Trusts in England.
effective_dosage: Best-practice advice (1 session + 2 optional sessions) vs. progressive exercise (up to 6 physiotherapy sessions).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but follow-up was 6 months post-injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a goal-directed movement intervention using a movement sensor to increase physical activity in hospitalized patients.
results_summary: The intervention increased patients' daily active minutes from 38 to 50, suggesting improved physical activity levels during hospitalization. Secondary outcomes like length of stay and complications were not significantly detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients admitted to pulmonology and nephrology/gastro-enterology wards.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included self-monitoring, goal-setting, and exercise posters).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability of commonly assessed biomarkers in clinically stable COPD patients over a 3-month period.
results_summary: The study showed excellent agreement between baseline and three-month follow-up values for FEV, indicating stability in biomarkers for clinically stable COPD patients. Outliers with significant variability between tests were identified, but clinical features did not significantly differ between outliers and others.
population_specificity: 89 individuals with clinically stable COPD (70.5 ± 6.7 years old, 61% male, 40 pack-year smoking history, 24.7% current smokers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of a lower limb walking exoskeleton on quality of life and functional independence in patients with motor complete spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found a non-significant trend toward improved quality of life in the exoskeleton-assisted walking group, while functional independence scores improved in both groups, with only the conventional group showing significant improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with motor complete spinal cord injury (SCI) (n=16).
effective_dosage: 40-50 minutes, 5 times/week using an AIDER powered robotic exoskeleton.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a physical activity program (DIAfit) on improving physical fitness, body composition, and cardiometabolic health in individuals with type 2 diabetes, comparing two exercise frequency variants.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in aerobic fitness (11% increase), body composition, and cardiometabolic parameters, except for lean body mass, triglycerides, and cholesterol. No major differences were observed between the two exercise frequency groups, except for a slightly larger weight reduction in the standard program.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes (mean age 59.7 years, 48% women).
effective_dosage: Standard group: 3 sessions/week for 12 weeks; alternative group: 1 session/week for 4 weeks, then 2 sessions/week for 16 weeks (total 36 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of postoperative exercise based on gait analysis versus conventional exercise in improving pain, disability, and gait symmetry in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: The study found that gait analysis-based exercise led to significant improvements in pain intensity, walking, standing, social life, and gait symmetry (stride length, hip flexion, knee flexion, and ankle dorsiflexion) compared to conventional exercise at 6 months post-intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) who underwent standardized surgical procedures.
study_duration: 2 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the bidirectional causal relationship between physical activity (including walking) and mental health/substance use disorders using Mendelian Randomisation.
results_summary: Accelerometer-based walking was associated with a lower risk of depression and cigarette smoking, suggesting a protective effect. However, the study did not isolate walking's effects from other forms of physical activity.
population_specificity: Derived from UK Biobank data (large-scale cohort) and genetic studies (Psychiatric Genomics Consortium, GWAS and Sequencing Consortium of Alcohol and Nicotine Use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of isolated transcatheter tricuspid valve repair (ITTVR) in improving functional outcomes and echocardiographic parameters in patients with tricuspid regurgitation (TR).
results_summary: ITTVR significantly improved NYHA functional class, reduced TR severity, and enhanced 6-minute walking distance by an average of +47.077 meters. Echocardiographic parameters also improved, though LVEF and PASP showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation (TR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if age-related differences in mobility could be predicted by upper-limb motor behavior during a standard mobility task (TUG test).
results_summary: The study found that age-related decline in mobility performance was more pronounced under dual-task and fast conditions, with significant correlations between arm movements and fast TUG performance, suggesting upper-limb behavior can predict gait-related parameters.
population_specificity: 60 healthy individuals divided into three age groups: young (mean 26 years), middle-aged (mean 48 years), and old (mean 68 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, usability, and potential clinical effects of the MAK exoskeleton for gait rehabilitation in stroke patients.
results_summary: The MAK exoskeleton was found to be safe with no serious adverse events reported. Muscle strength increased after treatment, but no changes were observed in range of motion.
population_specificity: Six participants with stroke.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 1 hour per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and acceptability of a wearable device and telehealth counseling intervention to promote physical activity (walking) early after lumbar spine surgery.
results_summary: The intervention was feasible and acceptable, with high retention rates and participant satisfaction. Both groups showed improvements in steps per day and patient-reported outcomes, but only the intervention group improved in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA).
population_specificity: Patients recovering from lumbar spine surgery (n=16 randomized).
effective_dosage: Not specified (step goals were set but exact amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the SARC-F questionnaire's role in screening for sarcopenia and predicting postoperative ambulation failure and overall survival in elderly patients undergoing major urologic cancer surgery.
results_summary: The SARC-F questionnaire effectively discriminated postoperative ambulation failure (AUC 0.856 in males, 0.813 in females) and was associated with shorter overall survival, particularly in patients with scores >4. It showed weak to moderate correlations with psoas muscle density but negligible correlations with psoas muscle index.
population_specificity: 815 patients (91% male, median age 72) undergoing elective major surgery for urologic cancer.
study_duration: Preoperative screening with postoperative follow-up (median 515 days for survival analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of using the PASCAL system for tricuspid transcatheter edge-to-edge repair (T-TEER) in patients with severe tricuspid regurgitation, focusing on procedural success, symptom improvement, and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found high procedural success rates (83.5%) and significant improvements in NYHA functional class, 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), and tricuspid regurgitation severity post-procedure. These improvements were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Patients with severe tricuspid regurgitation, mean age 71.0 to 80.3 years, 25.0 to 63.6% females.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 30 days to 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of duplex ultrasound (DUS) surveillance versus clinical surveillance (pulse palpation, arterial pressure index, or angiography) on outcomes after lower limb revascularization in people with lower extremity atherosclerotic disease (LEAD).
results_summary: The study found no clear difference between DUS and standard surveillance in preventing limb amputation, morbidity, or mortality after lower limb revascularization. DUS may increase re-intervention rates but showed little to no difference in limb salvage rate, graft patency, or quality of life.
population_specificity: People with lower extremity atherosclerotic disease (LEAD) who underwent lower limb revascularization, primarily bypass grafting.
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed at short-term (≤2 years) and long-term (>2 years) time points.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a written physical activity prescription combined with a pedometer increased physical activity more effectively than verbal advice in patients with cardiovascular disease risk in primary care.
results_summary: The study found that prescribing physical activity did not significantly change total weekly energy expenditure but slightly increased moderate-intensity activity duration and step counts, particularly among the most sedentary participants. The prescription group showed a clinically higher average step count increase of 5256 steps/week over a year, with even greater improvements in the most sedentary subgroup.
population_specificity: Patients aged 35 to 74 years with cardiovascular disease risk (hypertension, dyslipidaemia, or diabetes) who were insufficiently active.
effective_dosage: Experimental group received a written, personalised prescription for daily step numbers; control group received verbal advice to do at least 15 minutes of rapid walking or equivalent daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether unsupervised Nordic pole walk advice alone or combined with supervised or home-based structured exercise improved physical activity in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in physical activity outcomes at 1 year between groups, though short-term differences were observed at 3 and 6 months. The addition of structured exercise did not improve long-term physical activity compared to unsupervised walking advice alone.
population_specificity: 166 patients with intermittent claudication (mean age 72 years, 41% women).
study_duration: 12 months (with additional 6-month exercise programs for some groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of pulmonary artery denervation (PADN) on 1-year outcomes in patients with Group 1 pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: The study found that PADN plus a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor (PDE-5i) significantly reduced clinical worsening compared to a sham procedure plus PDE-5i, with lower rates of PAH-related hospitalizations, worsening functional class, and need for additional treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with Group 1 pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Bushen Zhuanggu tablet combined with routine treatment (calcium and vitamin D) in improving bone mineral density, functional recovery, and fracture prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis patients.
results_summary: The combination of Bushen Zhuanggu tablet with basic treatment (group A) showed a significantly higher effective rate (98.33%) compared to basic treatment alone (80.00%) or Bushen Zhuanggu tablet alone (93.33%). The combined treatment improved BMD, regulated calcium and phosphorus metabolism, enhanced limb function, and improved quality of life.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal osteoporosis patients (n=180) from community cohorts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of brisk walking versus Baduanjin exercise on reducing fall risk in elderly individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that brisk walking, along with Baduanjin exercise, was evaluated for its impact on fall risk, gait, balance, muscle strength, and cognitive function in elderly MCI patients, with outcomes measured over 12 weeks and a follow-up period.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, three sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the efficacy of a multi-component behavioral intervention for increasing physical activity levels (including walking) and self-efficacy for exercise among university students in Jordan.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased moderate physical activity and walking levels, with the intervention group showing a mean change of 503 METs/week in moderate activity and walking, and 3,000 steps/day compared to the control group. The intervention also improved self-efficacy for exercise and reduced BMI in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Students at Philadelphia University in Jordan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (behavioral intervention components included goal setting, self-monitoring, feedback, text reminders, and Facebook interaction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of ultrasound-guided versus electrical-stimulation-guided botulinum toxin injections for triceps surae spasticity in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in efficacy between ultrasound-guided and electrical-stimulation-guided injections for reducing spasticity or improving walking speed. Ultrasound-guided injections were faster to administer.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with triceps surae spasticity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Swiss ball stabilization training (SBST) and stable surface stabilization training (SSST) on trunk control, abdominal muscle thickness, balance, and motor skills in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: SBST significantly improved trunk control, motor skills, and thickness of specific abdominal muscles compared to SSST, while SSST showed greater improvement in external oblique muscle thickness. No significant difference was found in balance scores between the groups.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (aged 6-12 years, Gross Motor Function Classification System levels I-III).
study_duration: 5 weeks of intervention, 9 weeks of follow-up.
