study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinimetric properties of five clinically feasible measures of lower-limb extensor muscle strength in neurological rehabilitation settings.
results_summary: The load cell and hand-held dynamometry (HHD) were the most discriminative tests and resistant to floor/ceiling effects, with the load cell superior in clinical utility. The manual muscle test (MMT) and functional sit-to-stand (STS) test scored perfectly for clinical utility but were susceptible to floor/ceiling effects.
population_specificity: 36 participants with leg weakness due to neurological conditions/injuries, ranging from non-ambulant to independently ambulant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic non-specific low back pain (cNSLBP) affects action strategies during a horizontal aperture crossing task involving walking and shoulder rotation.
results_summary: cNSLBP participants minimized shoulder rotation for smaller apertures (1.18 times shoulder width) compared to asymptomatic adults (1.33 times), walked slower, and adapted movements without correlation to pain perception levels. The task differentiated cNSLBP participants from pain-free individuals without measuring pain levels.
population_specificity: 15 asymptomatic adults and 15 participants with chronic non-specific low back pain.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking task, not a dosage-based intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a structured early mobilization (EM) protocol on the level of mobilization, muscle strength, and activities of daily living (LADL) in critical care patients.
results_summary: The structured EM protocol increased the level of mobilization from day 1 to day 7 compared to conventional physiotherapy, but it did not improve muscle strength or LADL after ICU and hospital discharge.
population_specificity: Adult critical care patients in the ICU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a clinical prediction rule (CPR) using pinprick sensory testing to predict future independent walking ability after spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: Pinprick testing at the S1 dermatome (lateral heels) within 31 days of SCI accurately predicted independent walking ability one year post-injury. Normal sensation indicated good prognosis, partial sensation fair prognosis, and no sensation poor prognosis.
population_specificity: Individuals with traumatic spinal cord injury (N=3679).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the associations between changes in six-minute walking test (6MWT) parameters and clinical indicators in patients with nontuberculous mycobacterial pulmonary disease (NTM-PD).
results_summary: The study found that decreased walking distance and increased dyspnea over time in NTM-PD patients correlated with worsening health-related quality of life and pulmonary function, suggesting 6MWT changes can help assess patient condition.
population_specificity: 188 patients with NTM-PD (median age 67 years) visiting outpatient clinics at Keio University Hospital.
study_duration: Data collected from April 2012 to March 2020 (longitudinal follow-up, exact duration per patient not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of placenta-derived mesenchymal stem cells (P-MSCs) for improving blood flow and physical performance in patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI).
results_summary: The study found that intramuscular administration of P-MSCs was safe and well tolerated, with potential improvements in physical performance and reduced inflammation in CLI patients. All tested dosages, including the highest dose, showed no severe adverse effects.
population_specificity: Nine patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the minimal clinically important difference (MCID) for 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) among inpatients with subacute cardiac disease to assess the efficacy of physiotherapy interventions.
results_summary: The study found that the MCID for 6MWD in patients with subacute cardiovascular disease ranged from 27.5 to 38.6 meters, indicating a clinically meaningful improvement in walking distance. The results were consistent across patient and physiotherapist assessments.
population_specificity: Inpatients with subacute cardiac disease (n=35).
study_duration: Approximately 1 week between baseline and follow-up measurements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of leisure-time walking on lowering blood pressure in adults with hypertension.
results_summary: Leisure-time walking reduced systolic blood pressure by -8.36 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure by -5.03 mmHg, though the certainty of the evidence was low. Moderate-intensity leisure-time physical activity also showed reductions in blood pressure.
population_specificity: Adults living with hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the cardiovascular effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) versus psychotherapy-enhanced lifestyle intervention (PELI) in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that RYGB improved cardiopulmonary capacity and quality of life compared to PELI, with clinically relevant effect sizes.
population_specificity: Obese patients (mean BMI 48.2 kg/m², median age 38 years, 88% women) with an indication for RYGB and able to perform treadmill cardiopulmonary exercise testing.
study_duration: 12 months post-randomization, with optional reassessment at 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of various obesity treatments, including supervised walking combined with hydroxycitric acid and a controlled diet, to determine optimal therapeutic options.
results_summary: Supervised walking combined with hydroxycitric acid and a 2000-kcal/d diet was ranked as the second most effective treatment for obesity in trials involving both men and women, with a high P-score (0.92). The study did not isolate walking's individual effects but highlighted its efficacy in combination therapy.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (both men and women, women only, and men only).
effective_dosage: Supervised walking (specific duration/frequency not detailed) combined with hydroxycitric acid, 4667 mg 3 times daily, and a 2000-kcal/d diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify age-related differences in gait characteristics, functional evaluation, and cardiopulmonary metabolic energy consumption while walking among older adults subdivided into young-old (65-74 years) and old-old (75-84 years) groups.
results_summary: The old-old group showed significantly lower functional performance, gait velocity, stride length, and altered joint kinematics/kinetics compared to the young-old group, indicating age-related declines in gait efficiency and mobility. These findings suggest that older adults (75-84 years) may require tailored interventions to mitigate fall risks associated with aging-related gait changes.
population_specificity: 62 older adults (31 young-old: 65-74 years; 31 old-old: 75-84 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of various exercise interventions, including walking, for improving hip function, daily living activities, walking capacity, and balance in patients with hip fracture.
results_summary: Resistance exercise (RE) was ranked most effective for improving hip function, followed by balance exercise (BE), which was best for enhancing daily living activities. Walking capacity was indirectly assessed, but the abstract does not specify its standalone efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with hip fracture

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore diagnostic methods for fibromyalgia, including walking test performance, and potential treatments.
results_summary: The abstract mentions walking test performance as part of diagnostic measures but does not provide specific results on its efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Individuals with fibromyalgia, including juvenile forms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether wearable physical activity monitoring devices with feedback could increase daily walking activity and improve physical capacities in patients with cardiovascular disease (CVD).
results_summary: The study found that using wearable physical activity monitoring devices significantly improved daily step counts, particularly in interventions shorter than 3 months, but did not significantly affect 6-MWT distance or V̇O2 peak.
population_specificity: Patients with CVD over 18 years of age who had completed a cardiac rehabilitation program.
study_duration: Varied (less than 3 months vs. 3 months or longer)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acute cardiovascular safety and analgesic efficacy of intrathecal oxytocin in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in hypotension duration, vasopressor requirements, physical therapy metrics, opioid use, or pain scores between the oxytocin and placebo groups. Intrathecal oxytocin did not negatively impact cardiovascular safety or analgesic outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing primary total hip arthroplasty surgery (90 participants: 44 oxytocin, 46 placebo).
effective_dosage: 100 μg intrathecal oxytocin administered once prior to spinal anesthetic.
study_duration: Acute effects assessed over 24 hours post-administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week rehabilitation program (including exercise, education, dietary, and psychological support) added to usual care improves respiratory symptoms, fatigue, functional capacity, mental health, and quality of life in post-COVID-19 pneumonia patients compared to usual care alone.
results_summary: The rehabilitation group showed significantly greater improvement in the COPD Assessment Test score compared to usual care, indicating enhanced recovery in respiratory symptoms and overall health post-COVID-19.
population_specificity: Patients with COVID-19 pneumonia, 6-8 weeks post-hospital discharge, excluding those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, respiratory failure, or heart failure.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included exercise, education, dietary, and psychological support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of exercise therapy, including walking, in improving bowel preparation quality for colonoscopy and to characterize exercise programs used for this purpose.
results_summary: The study found that exercise therapy, including walking, improved the quality of bowel preparation, but there was insufficient evidence to assess effects on procedure-related indicators, adverse events, or willingness to repeat preparation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colonoscopy (1,109 participants across five studies).
effective_dosage: 3,000-10,000 steps or 0.5-1.9 hours of exercise (timing varied during or 1 hour after laxative intake).
study_duration: Not specified (single session during bowel preparation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the interaction between fitness (via arm ergometry exercise) and disability in progressive MS, focusing on functional and structural brain connectivity and motor/cognitive outcomes.
results_summary: The study found increased functional connectivity in highly connected brain regions of the exercise group, with no structural changes. Fitness moderated the relationship between network disruption and functional outcomes, showing stronger correlations in more disrupted networks.
population_specificity: 34 persons with advanced progressive MS (mean age 53, 71% female, mean disease duration 17 years, walking restriction <100m without aid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of atypical tibial fracture in a patient with metastatic bone disease due to breast cancer after long-term denosumab use.
results_summary: The study found that an 82-year-old woman on long-term denosumab therapy developed an atypical tibial fracture, which required surgical treatment and showed bone fusion after four months. The case highlights the need for awareness of atypical fractures in patients using denosumab for metastatic bone disease.
population_specificity: 82-year-old Japanese woman with stage 4 breast cancer and multiple bone metastases.
effective_dosage: Yearly intravenous denosumab for 4 years (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine muscle activity impairments during functional tasks like walking in individuals with hip-related pain or pathology.
results_summary: The study found variable impairments in muscle activity, with more pronounced differences in those with severe hip pathology (e.g., hip osteoarthritis). Non-pooled data indicated limited evidence overall.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip-related pain (femoroacetabular impingement syndrome, labral tears) or hip osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of pelvic tilt taping on muscle strength, pelvic inclination, and gait function in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that posterior pelvic tilt taping (PPTT) significantly improved pelvic alignment and walking speed in stroke patients, with additional benefits observed when combined with lateral pelvic tilt taping (LPTT).
population_specificity: 60 patients with stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the effect of home-based indoor physical activity (including walking) on psychosocial outcomes and mobility in community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The review found moderately certain evidence that home-based exercise programs reduced fear of falling and may improve psychosocial outcomes (mental health and quality of life) and walking speed (mobility). The evidence ranged from very low to certain for these improvements.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (total of 1004 participants across 11 studies).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of physical conditioning training on distance walked and maximum oxygen consumption (VO₂ max) in individuals with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Physical conditioning training increased distance walked by 46.34 m (p = 0.07) and VO₂ max by 5.93 ml·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹ (p < 0.001) in children and adolescents with cerebral palsy. The results suggest clinically beneficial improvements in cardiorespiratory fitness.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with cerebral palsy, aged 5–18 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-velocity power training (HVPT) versus traditional resistance training (TRT) on functional performance in older adults.
results_summary: HVPT showed weak-to-moderate improvements in Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) and Timed Up and Go (TUG) tests compared to TRT, but effects on other outcomes were uncertain. The overall evidence quality was low, and the clinical significance of the benefits remains unclear.
population_specificity: Older adults aged over 60, regardless of health status, baseline functional capacity, or residential status.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of testosterone, androgens, and SARMs on functional limitations related to aging and chronic diseases, including their impact on muscle mass, strength, and mobility.
results_summary: Testosterone treatment increased lean body mass, muscle strength, leg power, and aerobic capacity but did not consistently improve walking speed. It also improved bone mineral density, sexual function, and depressive symptoms in some populations.
population_specificity: Healthy men, hypogonadal men, older men with mobility limitations, menopausal women, and HIV-infected women with weight loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of PENG and SFIB blocks in controlling postoperative pain and improving functional recovery after total hip arthroplasty via the posterolateral approach.
results_summary: The study found that PENG blocks were noninferior to SFIB blocks in pain control 6 hours after surgery, with no significant differences in pain trajectories or functional recovery metrics (timed-up-and-go, walking tests, and quality-of-recovery scores) over the first 48 postoperative hours.
population_specificity: 102 patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty via the posterolateral approach under spinal anesthesia.
effective_dosage: SFIB group received 40 ml ropivacaine 0.375%, PENG group received 20 ml ropivacaine 0.75%.
study_duration: Pain and functional recovery were assessed up to 48 hours post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a prehabilitation program involving Nordic Walking, resistance training, and health education could improve postoperative arm functionality and other outcomes in breast cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant therapy.
results_summary: The study suggests that the prehabilitation program may enhance postoperative recovery of upper arm function, improve physical performance, and boost health-related quality of life, though final results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer scheduled for surgery and undergoing neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 2 weekly sessions of 75 minutes of Nordic Walking plus muscle strengthening exercises and health education.
study_duration: From the fourth month of treatment until surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait characteristics (spatiotemporal, kinematic, and kinetic) during level walking between total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that UKA was superior to TKA in walking speed, stride length, maximum knee flexion at loading, vertical ground reaction forces, knee internal rotational moment, knee extension, and KSS Function score, with no significant differences in other gait parameters.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA) or unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relevance, acceptability, and feasibility of introducing the Walk With Ease (WWE) programme into a UK context for adults with arthritis.
results_summary: Participants found WWE relevant and acceptable, with 99% recommending it to others. Improvements were observed in physical performance, arthritis symptoms, motivation, health, and social well-being.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) with doctor-diagnosed arthritis, BMI ≥25 kg/m², and <150 min/week of moderate/vigorous physical activity, predominantly older women (76% aged ≥60 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (6-week walking programme, either instructor-led or self-directed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of combined aerobic and resistance exercise (CARE) on physical function, aerobic capacity, dialysis adequacy, and health-related quality of life in patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis (MHD).
results_summary: CARE improved peak oxygen uptake, six-minute walking test, sit-to-stand tests, dialysis adequacy, blood pressure, hemoglobin, and several domains of health-related quality of life in MHD patients. No significant changes were observed in mental health-related quality of life or certain biochemical markers like C-reactive protein and electrolytes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis (MHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of physical exercise programs, including walking, for treating individuals with non-ulcerated chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence for any clear benefits of exercise on CVI symptoms, venous function, or quality of life, with no significant differences observed in most outcomes between exercise and control groups. Results were inconsistent and limited by small sample sizes and methodological weaknesses.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-ulcerated chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise protocols varied between studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 20 Hz transcutaneous auricular vagus nerve stimulation (taVNS) improves gait impairments in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients and to investigate the underlying neural mechanisms.
results_summary: Active taVNS improved gait characteristics (step length, stride velocity, stride length, and step length variability) in PD patients compared to sham treatment after 7 days. No significant differences were found in other clinical scores (UPDRS III, Timed Up and Go, Tinetti Balance, and Gait scores). Hemodynamic responses in the left primary somatosensory cortex decreased after taVNS therapy.
population_specificity: 22 PD patients and 14 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a standardized definition and measurement approach for preclinical mobility limitation (PCML), focusing on walking and other mobility tasks.
results_summary: The study concluded that PCML should be measured using both patient-reported and performance-based methods, with walking (distance and speed), stairs, and transfers as key tasks. It also supported the term PCML to describe early mobility changes without overt disability.
population_specificity: Older adults with preclinical mobility limitations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide updated guidelines on preventing foot ulcers in persons with diabetes, including recommendations on walking and foot protection.
results_summary: The study recommends educating at-risk individuals to avoid walking without suitable foot protection and suggests that a total increase in weight-bearing activity of 1000 steps/day is likely safe regarding ulceration risk. Therapeutic footwear with plantar pressure relief during walking is advised to prevent ulcer recurrence.
population_specificity: Persons with diabetes at risk of foot ulceration, categorized by low, moderate, or high risk.
effective_dosage: 1000 steps/day increase in weight-bearing activity (suggested for low-to-moderate risk individuals).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of exoskeleton-assisted gait training on cortical activity and functional outcomes in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The Healbot G group showed significantly higher cortical activity, improved walking ability (FAC), voluntary strength (MI-Lower), and spatial step symmetry ratio compared to treadmill training. No significant difference in cortical activity was observed between affected and unaffected hemispheres after training.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients with Functional Ambulatory Category scale (FAC) scores between 2 and 4.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of training, 10 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of intra-articular polynucleotide (IA PN) injections versus high molecular weight hyaluronic acid (IA HMWHA) injections for treating knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in efficacy or safety between IA PN and IA HMWHA injections, with both showing similar improvements in pain and functional outcomes. Adverse events, such as pain at the injection site and swelling, were reported but were similar in both groups.
population_specificity: 60 patients (15 men, 45 women, aged 64.5 ± 7.5 years) with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 1-4).
effective_dosage: Three intra-articular injections at intervals of 1 week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether semaglutide improves symptoms, physical limitations, and exercise function in addition to weight loss in patients with the obesity phenotype of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: The abstract describes the design and baseline characteristics of two trials (STEP-HFpEF and STEP-HFpEF DM) but does not report specific results regarding the effects of semaglutide on the studied outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with HFpEF and a body mass index ≥30 kg/m², including those with type 2 diabetes (STEP-HFpEF DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of bilateral asymmetrical limb PNF exercises versus Swiss ball exercises on pain, disability, and lumbar multifidus activity in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The PNF group showed significant improvements in pain (during sitting, standing, and walking), disability, and left-side lumbar multifidus activity compared to the Swiss ball group, though no significant differences were found for right-side activity or lumbar range of motion.
population_specificity: 150 patients with chronic low back pain.
effective_dosage: 15 sessions of exercises (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied over the course of 15 sessions.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of torso training on unstable surfaces on lower limb motor function in patients with incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Torso training on unstable surfaces improved gait (stride length, stride frequency, comfortable walking speed), lower limb muscle strength, balance function, lower limb function, mobility, and nerve function in patients with incomplete spinal cord injury. The study group (unstable surface training) showed better outcomes compared to the control group (stable surface training).
population_specificity: 80 patients with incomplete spinal cord injury caused by thoracolumbar fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and re-analyze evidence from systematic reviews on the effects of SGLT2 inhibitors in heart failure with mildly reduced or preserved ejection fraction, including their impact on health-related quality of life and cardiorespiratory capacity.
results_summary: The study found that SGLT2 inhibitors significantly improved health-related quality of life and 6-minute walking distance, with a lower risk of serious adverse events compared to placebo. The composite outcome of cardiovascular mortality or hospitalization for heart failure showed a significant favorable effect.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure with mildly reduced (HFmrEF) or preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a supervised hospital walking program (STRIDE) on discharge to skilled-nursing facilities, length of stay, and inpatient falls in older hospitalized veterans.
results_summary: The study found that hospitalizations during the STRIDE implementation period had lower odds of discharge to a skilled-nursing facility, with no significant changes in hospital length of stay or inpatient falls. The program's reach was limited and variable.
population_specificity: Veterans aged 60 years or older, community-dwelling, and admitted for 2 or more days to a participating medicine ward at one of 8 Veterans Affairs hospitals.
study_duration: The study period spanned from 20 August 2017 to 19 August 2019, but the exact duration of the walking program for individual patients is not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of motor rehabilitation interventions, including walking-related therapies, in people with transtibial amputations due to peripheral arterial disease or diabetes.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence that gait training protocols and motor imaging combined with physical walking practice showed little or no difference in mobility assessments or adverse events. Outcomes like prosthesis use, mortality, quality of life, and phantom limb pain were not reported.
population_specificity: People with transtibial amputations resulting from peripheral arterial disease or diabetes (dysvascular causes).
study_duration: One study assessed outcomes from day 3 to day 10 post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of walking, alone and combined with time-restricted feeding (TRF), on body weight, BMI, body composition, and blood lipid levels in female college students with hidden obesity.
results_summary: Walking alone significantly reduced body weight and BMI in female college students with hidden obesity. However, the combination of walking and TRF did not show superior effects compared to walking or TRF alone.
population_specificity: Female college students aged 18-22 years with hidden obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prognosis and complications of cervical odontoid fractures in elderly patients and identify factors associated with worsening ambulation after 6 months.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in complications or ambulation outcomes among treatment strategies (nonsurgical, conversion to surgery, or initial surgery). Worsening ambulation after 6 months was associated with age over 80, pre-injury walking assistance needs, cerebrovascular disease, and a modified frailty index score ≥2.
population_specificity: Elderly patients aged 65+ with cervical odontoid fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and clinical outcomes of using EMDR therapy to treat functional neurological disorder (FND), including walking difficulties.
results_summary: The study will assess feasibility (recruitment, retention, safety, etc.) and clinical outcomes (FND symptoms, quality of life, etc.) but results are not yet available as it is a proposed trial.
population_specificity: 50 adult patients diagnosed with FND.
study_duration: Outcomes measured at baseline, 3, 6, and 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare lifestyle factors, including walking status, before and after the COVID-19 pandemic in Korea.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant differences in walking status between 2019 and 2021, but did not specify the nature or direction of these changes. No direct efficacy or safety outcomes related to walking were reported.
population_specificity: Korean adults from the Korea National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (2019 and 2021).
study_duration: Not applicable (observational study comparing two time points)

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of functional electrical stimulation (FES) in improving walking in adults with upper motor neuron lesions through an umbrella review of systematic reviews.
results_summary: FES improved walking speed in stroke patients with both immediate (orthotic) and long-term (therapeutic) benefits, though evidence certainty was low. In multiple sclerosis, FES had an orthotic but no therapeutic effect, while in spinal cord injury, FES improved speed but was no better than orthosis alone when combined.
population_specificity: Adults with upper motor neuron lesions (stroke, spinal cord injury, multiple sclerosis, mixed populations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week lifestyle modification program (including moderate-intensity treadmill walking) could improve metabolic syndrome components and erectile dysfunction in obese men with chronic plaque psoriasis.
results_summary: The lifestyle modification group showed significant improvements in body mass index, psoriasis severity, erectile dysfunction, and metabolic syndrome components compared to the waitlist group. The waitlist group did not demonstrate similar improvements.
population_specificity: Obese men with chronic plaque psoriasis, mild to moderate erectile dysfunction, and metabolic syndrome (n=60).
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity treadmill walking (specific frequency and duration not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of sacubitril/valsartan (SAC/VAL) in improving cardiac function and walking capacity (via the 6-minute walking test) in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) undergoing peritoneal dialysis (PD).
results_summary: SAC/VAL improved cardiac function, HF scoring efficacy, and 6-minute walk distance compared to the control group, with more pronounced improvements in echocardiographic parameters, serological indicators, and blood pressure.
population_specificity: Patients with HFpEF undergoing peritoneal dialysis (HFpEF&PD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fatigue on walking kinematics, kinetics, and energy cost in children with cerebral palsy (CP) compared to typically developing children.
results_summary: Prolonged walking led to slight deterioration in gait kinematics for both groups, with specific changes in knee and ankle flexion in children with CP. No significant changes were observed in kinetics or energy cost of walking.
population_specificity: 12 children with CP (mean age 12 years 9 months) and 15 typically developing children (mean age 10 years 8 months).
effective_dosage: 6-minute walking exercise at comfortable speed, 2 minutes of moderate-intensity walking, and 4 minutes walking after moderate-intensity walking.
study_duration: Single session with stages totaling approximately 12 minutes of walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether hip and knee osteoarthritis (OA) indirectly increases cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk through reduced activity (e.g., walking) and whether NSAID use is correlated with CVD.
results_summary: The study found that hip and knee OA are linked to increased CVD morbidity and mortality, with cardiac risk rising with walking difficulties, disability scores, and OA severity. No study linked NSAID use to cardiac disease.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip and/or knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness and determinants of recruitment strategies for engaging adults in organized physical activity (PA) programs, specifically walking.
results_summary: The study found limited evaluation evidence on successful recruitment strategies for organized PA programs, with culturally sensitive and socially inclusive strategies showing promise for hard-to-reach populations. Improved reporting and measurement of recruitment strategies are needed to better understand their effectiveness.
population_specificity: Adults participating in organized physical activity programs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a multi-disciplinary treatment approach (including sildenafil, macitentan, and methylprednisolone) on a patient with hepatitis C-related pulmonary hypertension, nephrotic syndrome, and polymyositis, with walking distance as a secondary outcome measure.
results_summary: The patient showed significant improvement in 6-minute walking distance (from 100 to 300 meters) and a reduction in pulmonary artery pressure (to 50 mmHg) after 3 months of treatment. Long-term follow-up was recommended to confirm further efficacy and safety.
population_specificity: A 57-year-old woman with chronic hepatitis C infection, pulmonary hypertension, nephrotic syndrome, and polymyositis.
effective_dosage: Not specified for walking; treatment included sildenafil, macitentan, and methylprednisolone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the reproducibility of BOLD imaging for evaluating lower extremity perfusion and explore its correlation with walking performance in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found good to perfect interuser reproducibility for perfusion parameters, with significant differences in perfusion between PAD patients and controls. Perfusion parameters (MIV, TTP, Grad) correlated with walking performance, such as lower MIV in patients with poor SPPB scores and negative correlation between TTP and 6-minute walk distance.
population_specificity: Seventeen PAD patients (mean age 67 ± 6 years, 15 males) and eight older adult controls.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (imaging study, no dosage administered).
study_duration: Not specified (observational study without intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether self-reported ability to walk 4 meters and wash oneself predicts survival and functional status in patients with pre-terminal cancer.
results_summary: The study found that the ability to walk 4 meters and wash independently were significant predictors of survival, with impaired walking and washing associated with worse symptoms, reduced physical function, and shorter survival. Patients who could walk or wash had better functional outcomes and longer survival.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with pre-terminal cancer (estimated 1-12 months prognosis) at an academic inpatient palliative care unit (52% female, mean age 64 ± 12 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (observational study, no intervention dosage).
study_duration: Observation period lasted 27 months, with median patient survival of 46 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the LOCOBOT system improved weight-bearing ratio (WBR) and balance in static standing for patients recovering from total hip arthroplasty (THA).
results_summary: The LOCOBOT group showed significantly higher WBR and weight-bearing amount (WBA) on the operated side and lower WBA on the non-operated side compared to the control group by the 12th day post-THA. The system also improved balance ability, as indicated by reduced outer diameter area (ODA).
population_specificity: 20 patients with unilateral hip osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 or 4) who underwent primary uncemented THA.
effective_dosage: 10 minutes of LOCOBOT use per session (within a 40-minute rehabilitation session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify cognitive overload and its influence on walking and auditory addition and subtraction performance in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that patients with Parkinson's disease experienced cognitive overload during dual-task conditions, leading to impaired gait control and calculation accuracy, particularly in subtraction tasks. Healthy controls also made more errors during dual tasks, but the effect was more pronounced in the Parkinson's group.
population_specificity: Sixteen patients with Parkinson's disease and 15 age- and sex-matched healthy elderly controls.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (behavioral tasks, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of backward locomotor training (BLT) versus forward locomotor training (FLT) on gait speed, dynamic balance control, and the underlying mechanisms (compensation vs. recovery) in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: BLT improved gait speed and balance confidence but relied on compensatory mechanisms (increased nonparetic limb propulsion). FLT improved paretic limb propulsion, suggesting recovery, but did not enhance gait speed. Neither training improved dynamic balance control, indicating a need for balance-specific interventions.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=18).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified (only session count provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical activity levels, particularly walking, and health-related quality of life between lung cancer patients in China and Australia.
results_summary: At baseline, Chinese patients walked significantly more than Australian patients (210 vs. 55 min/wk). Over 8 weeks, Chinese patients increased walking time, while Australian patients reduced physical activity levels.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed lung cancer patients (71 from China, 90 from Australia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness and safety of circuit class therapy (CCT) on mobility in adults with stroke.
results_summary: CCT was found to improve walking capacity, gait speed, balance, and independent mobility in stroke survivors, with clinically meaningful effects. However, there was a non-significant trend toward increased falls during therapy.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years old diagnosed with stroke of any severity, at any stage, or in any setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a marker-less tracking system versus a marker-based system in calculating 3D joint angles for clinical gait analysis.
results_summary: The study found that kinematic data from marker-less and marker-based tracking systems were compared for hip, knee, and ankle angles across three planes, with Root Mean Square differences used to assess discrepancies.
population_specificity: Ten participants walking and jogging on a treadmill.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and evaluate the psychometric properties of tools used to assess exercise tolerance functions in persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) and recommend the best test for this purpose.
results_summary: The study found that whole-body exercise tests combined with gas exchange analysis had the best psychometric properties for assessing aerobic capacity in persons with MS (EDSS ≤6.5). Walk tests were deemed more suitable for assessing walking performance rather than exercise tolerance functions.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS), specifically those with mild to moderate disability (EDSS ≤6.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of vitamin D supplementation on functional, echocardiographic, and hormonal parameters in patients with heart failure and vitamin D deficiency.
results_summary: Vitamin D treatment improved the 6-minute walking test (6MWT) at 3 months and reduced PTH levels, but these effects were not sustained at 6 months. Compared to placebo, vitamin D treatment did not significantly influence final outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure and vitamin D deficiency (VD <20 ng/mL).
effective_dosage: 300,000 U of oral cholecalciferol initially, followed by 50,000 U/month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of Nordic walking (NW) versus specific strength training (ST) and a non-training control group on self-reported neck and shoulder pain among office workers.
results_summary: Both NW and ST significantly reduced pain intensity, with similar effectiveness, while the control group showed no change. Pain reduction persisted in the NW group but increased slightly in the ST group after 10 weeks post-intervention. No changes in strength or walking endurance were observed.
population_specificity: 34 female office workers with neck and shoulder pain.
effective_dosage: Twice per week for 30 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the accuracy of the eSHOE system for gait analysis compared to the GAITRite reference system, with the goal of enabling home-based monitoring for individuals with chronic locomotor system diseases.
results_summary: The eSHOE system demonstrated adequate accuracy, with average differences in gait parameters ranging from -0.046 to 0.045 seconds in patients and -0.029 to 0.029 seconds in healthy subjects, suggesting it is a viable tool for home-based gait analysis.
population_specificity: Eleven hip fracture patients (78.4 ± 7.7 years) and twelve healthy subjects (40.8 ± 9.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether anti-hypertensive medications worsen or improve leg ischemia in PAD patients, specifically assessing walking distance and ankle brachial pressure index.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of anti-hypertensive medications on MWD, PFWD, or ABPI, but a meta-regression suggested that reduced MAP correlated with increased MWD. Heterogeneity was high, and follow-up periods were generally short.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication due to peripheral artery disease (PAD).
study_duration: ≤ 6 weeks in 3 out of 5 studies (exact duration not specified for all)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between walking disturbances and bone-articular lesions or joint pains in patients with dialysis-related amyloidosis (DRA).
results_summary: The study found that knee joint pain was a significant contributor to walking disturbances in patients with DRA, and carpal tunnel syndrome appeared earlier than trigger finger since dialysis initiation.
population_specificity: 82 patients with clinical DRA from 20 hospitals in Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Evenup™ shoe-lift improved function and reduced pain in patients using a walking boot after lower-extremity injuries.
results_summary: All subjects showed improved function, reduced pain, increased range of motion, and strength. The intervention group using Evenup™ demonstrated clinically relevant improvements in low back pain disability (OSW) and lower extremity function (LEFS) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Thirty-four subjects undergoing unilateral lower-extremity orthopedic medical and rehabilitative care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of non-invasive ventilation (NIV) on physiological and perceptual responses during walking and other daily activities in different environmental conditions.
results_summary: NIV resulted in similar physiological and perceptual responses during walking in both temperate and hot-humid environments for healthy participants, but increased heart rate during more strenuous tasks. Tropical conditions did not alter responses during everyday tasks with NIV use.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify dual-task-related gait changes specific to Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases and assess their potential as prediagnostic markers.
results_summary: The study found that exacerbation of gait disorders under dual-task conditions could be characteristic of early-stage Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, suggesting these changes may serve as early diagnostic markers.
population_specificity: Individuals with prodromal Alzheimer's or Parkinson's diseases.

study_goal: The researchers investigated the relationship between right ventricular longitudinal strain (RVLS) and RV function parameters in pulmonary hypertension (PH) patients, categorized by WHO functional class.
results_summary: The study found that PH patients in WHO functional class III/IV had higher systolic pulmonary artery pressure (sPAP) and significant differences in global RVLS compared to those in class I/II.
population_specificity: 66 pulmonary hypertension (PH) patients divided into WHO functional class I/II (group 1) and III/IV (group 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exercise on brain activity during walking in healthy older adults, specifically identifying cortical regions activated by exercise training.
results_summary: The intervention group showed increased regional glucose metabolism in memory-related brain regions (left posterior entorhinal cortex, left superior temporal gyrus, and right superior temporopolar area) and greater step length in the right foot. The control group exhibited metabolic increases in motor and sensory areas, but no significant differences in FDG uptake were found between groups post-intervention.
population_specificity: 24 elderly women aged 75-83 years.
effective_dosage: Biweekly 90-minute sessions (aerobic exercise, strength training, and physical therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and outcomes of intramedullary nails (IMN) versus sliding hip screws (SHS) for treating AO/OTA 31-A2 trochanteric fractures.
results_summary: IMN fixation resulted in less operative blood loss, leg shortening, wound infections, shorter hospital stays, and quicker mobilization with walking aids compared to SHS, with no significant differences in other complications or 1-year mortality.
population_specificity: Patients with AO/OTA 31-A2 trochanteric fractures (909 participants from six RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher levels of leisure-time physical activity, including walking speed, were associated with longer leukocyte telomere length (LTL) in older women.
results_summary: The study found that higher levels of total leisure-time physical activity, moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, and faster walking speed were associated with longer LTL in older women, suggesting a potential anti-aging benefit.
population_specificity: 1476 older white and African American women (average age 79.2 years) from the Women's Health Initiative Objective Physical Activity and Cardiovascular Health study.
effective_dosage: Highest activity level (≥17.00 MET-hours/week) compared to lowest (<1.25 MET-hours/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of exercise, nutritional, drug, and combinational interventions, including walking, for treating sarcopenia in older people.
results_summary: Exercise interventions, including walking, showed potential in improving muscle mass, strength, and walking speed over 3 months. Combined interventions of exercise and nutrition also had positive effects on walking speed.
population_specificity: Older people with sarcopenia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate respiratory muscle strength and endurance in low-risk post-MI patients and assess the effects of a home-based walking program on these outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that low-risk post-MI patients had impaired respiratory muscle strength and endurance compared to healthy individuals, but the home-based walking program improved respiratory endurance and functional capacity.
population_specificity: Low-risk patients recently experiencing myocardial infarction (MI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge about lower extremity gait mechanics and quantify the impact of ankle osteoarthritis and total ankle arthroplasty (TAA) on mobility and balance.
results_summary: The study found that ankle osteoarthritis causes severe gait and balance dysfunction, and TAA alone does not fully restore normal walking mechanics due to persistent issues like limited ankle range of motion and balance deficits. Additional therapeutic interventions targeting balance and movement symmetry are needed for long-term functional improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with ankle osteoarthritis who underwent treatments like TAA, ankle fusion, or ankle distraction arthroplasty.
